title: If R1=R2=R3=R4=10 ohms and R=20 ohms, what is the equivalent resistor of the circuit? - Quora

response.answer_text: Welcome to the amazing world of electronics. I believe from the way you have written your question like other answers here you need to study the original question again or ask for some clarification. It is always good to have what is called in electronics a ‘circuit diagram’ showing the way electronic components are designed to work together to achieve a particular function. When learning about resistors the diagram will most likely show them wired as combinations of ‘Parallel’ and ‘Series’ wiring.  When Resistors are wired in series the two resistors values add up using the simple Rt = R1 + R2 formula. In this form they decrease (limit) what is called the ‘current’ (flow of electrons) in the circuit. Current(I) is measured in ‘amperes’ or ‘amps’ for short.  When Resistors are wired in Parallel they follow the following formula: 1/Rt = 1/R1 + 1/R2 With resistors wired in Parallel the current (I) in the circuit will increase. Any combination of Parallel and Series circuits connected together can be systematically worked through using the two formula above to find the equivalent resistance. To answer your question you need to find out how exactly all the 4 ten ohm resistors and the 20 ohm resistor are wired together, preferably with a circuit diagram. Main point is enjoy learning about electronics you may become very fascinated and find it stimulating. Most importantly it will help give you some insights of how the modern world actually works, which unfortunately is becoming a mysterious black art to many particularly if you ask them how their phone or computer or even a electric light actually works.

it depends on whether the resistors are connected in series or parallelin series R1 + R2 + R3 + R4 + R = 10 + 10 + 10 + 10 + 20 = 60 ohmsin parallel 1 / (1/R1 + 1/R2 + 1/R3 + 1/R4 + 1/R) = 1 / (1/10 + 1/10 + 1/10 + 1/10 + 1/20) = 1/(2/20 + 2/20 + 2/20 + 2/20 + 1/20) = 1/(9/20) = 20/9 = 2.2222 ohms

You need to copy your homework properly, so you can understand better and do your own homework.. If your teacher did not include the drawing, you should ask for better understanding.. the resistors need to be connected in some way to find the equivalent resistance!
The problem is unclear. Learn to make a labeled schematic. Assuming R1 - R4 are in series, the problem reduces to 40 ohms in parallel with 20 ohms = 13 1/3 ohms.
